ruleset.name: Migration Rules
ruleset.description: Contains rules about migrating from one JDK version to another. Don't use these rules directly, rather, use a wrapper ruleset such as migrating_to_13.xml.

rule.name: ReplaceVectorWithList
rule.message: Consider replacing this Vector with the newer java.util.List
rule.description: Consider replacing Vector usages with the newer java.util.ArrayList if expensive threadsafe operation is not required.

rule.name: ReplaceHashtableWithMap
rule.message: Consider replacing this Hashtable with the newer java.util.Map
rule.description: Consider replacing this Hashtable with the newer java.util.Map

rule.name: ReplaceEnumerationWithIterator
rule.message: Consider replacing this Enumeration with the newer java.util.Iterator
rule.description: Consider replacing this Enumeration with the newer java.util.Iterator

rule.name: AvoidEnumAsIdentifier
rule.message: Avoid using enum as an identifier; it's a reserved word in JDK 1.5
rule.description: Finds all places where 'enum' is used as an identifier.

rule.name: AvoidAssertAsIdentifier
rule.message: Avoid using assert as an identifier; it's a reserved word in JDK 1.4
rule.description: Finds all places where 'assert' is used as an identifier.

rule.name: IntegerInstantiation
rule.message: Avoid instantiating Integer objects. Call Integer.valueOf() instead.
rule.description: In JDK 1.5, calling new Integer() causes memory allocation. Integer.valueOf() is more memory friendly.

rule.name: ByteInstantiation
rule.message: Avoid instantiating Byte objects. Call Byte.valueOf() instead
rule.description: In JDK 1.5, calling new Byte() causes memory allocation. Byte.valueOf() is more memory friendly.

rule.name: ShortInstantiation
rule.message: Avoid instantiating Short objects. Call Short.valueOf() instead
rule.description: In JDK 1.5, calling new Short() causes memory allocation. Short.valueOf() is more memory friendly.

rule.name: LongInstantiation
rule.message: Avoid instantiating Long objects.Call Long.valueOf() instead
rule.description: In JDK 1.5, calling new Long() causes memory allocation. Long.valueOf() is more memory friendly.

rule.name: JUnit4TestShouldUseBeforeAnnotation
rule.message: JUnit 4 tests that set up tests should use the @Before annotation
rule.description: In JUnit 3, the setUp method was used to set up all data entities required in running tests. JUnit 4 skips the setUp method and executes all methods annotated with @Before before all tests

rule.name: JUnit4TestShouldUseAfterAnnotation
rule.message: JUnit 4 tests that clean up tests should use the @After annotation
rule.description: In JUnit 3, the tearDown method was used to clean up all data entities required in running tests. JUnit 4 skips the tearDown method and executes all methods annotated with @After after running each test

rule.name: JUnit4TestShouldUseTestAnnotation
rule.message: JUnit 4 tests that execute tests should use the @Test annotation
rule.description: In JUnit 3, the framework executed all methods which started with the word test as a unit test. In JUnit 4, only methods annotated with the @Test annotation are executed.

rule.name: JUnit4SuitesShouldUseSuiteAnnotation
rule.message: JUnit 4 indicates test suites via annotations, not the suite method.
rule.description: In JUnit 3, test suites are indicated by the suite() method. In JUnit 4, suites are indicated through the @RunWith(Suite.class) annotation.

rule.name: JUnitUseExpected
rule.message: In JUnit4, use the @Test(expected) annotation to denote tests that should throw exceptions
